results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response:
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market is determined by using valuation techniques. These techniques maximise the use of observable market data where it is available and rely as little as possible on entity specific estimates. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3.

results.question: What is the definition of deferred revenues?
gold_answer: Performance obligations for which payments have been received by the customer prior to revenue recognition.
results.markdown_table_response: Deferred revenue is a form of deferred compensation. Deferred compensation is a means to provide a financial incentive to a company's employees to work for the company for a specified period of time. The company provides the employee with a share of the deferred compensation, which is paid out based on the amount of time the employee works for the company. The deferred compensation is paid based on the employee's work for the company. Deferred compensation is a form of employee stock options, stock-based compensation, or other forms of non-cash compensation. Deferred compensation is typically provided to employees in the form of a percentage of their annual salary, or other compensation (such as a bonus) payable at a time when the employee is not performing work for the company.

results.json_rows_response:
Non-GAAP Operating Income
Non-GAAP operating income is a non-GAAP financial measure that excludes certain items such as discontinued operations and other non-recurring items. The non-GAAP operating income is calculated by taking the difference between GAAP operating income and the non-GAAP measure of non-GAAP operating income. The difference represents the difference between the GAAP and non-GAAP operating income. This non-GAAP operating income is then compared to the GAAP operating income. In the case of stock-based compensation, the non-GAAP measure of non-GAAP operating income includes the non-GAAP measure of GAAP operating income. In the case of amortization of intangible assets, the non-GAAP measure of non-GAAP operating income includes the non-GAAP measure of GAAP operating income.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response: Basic earnings per share (EPS) is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
results.csv_string_response:
Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted earnings per share is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted earnings per share when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted earnings per share.

Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. When determining the transaction price of the contract, an adjustment is made if payment from a customer occurs either significantly before or significantly after performance, resulting in a significant financing component. None of the Company’s licenses and collaboration agreements contained a significant financing component at either December 31, 2019 or 2018.

results.question: What is the $ change in the capital expenditures for Bell Wireless?

BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to last year, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

results.question: What are the capital expenditures for Bell Media in 2018 and 2019?
results.markdown_table_response:
BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

results.json_rows_response:
Net sales increased $19.7 million or 10.8% to $202.0 million in fiscal year 2018 from $182.2 million in fiscal year 2017. The increase was primarily driven by an increase in net sales in the distributor channel of $13.7 million, a $3.3 million increase in net sales in the OEM channel of the EMEA region and a $4.2 million increase in the EMS channel across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC regions. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in net sales of $1.2 million in the OEM channel across the Americas, APAC, and JPKO regions. In addition, there was a favorable impact of $7.6 million from foreign currency exchange primarily due to the change in the value of the Euro compared to the U.S. dollar.
Net sales are the total amount of sales by an organization for a specific period of time. Net sales are not necessarily the sales by the same organization for the same period.
